page.title: 15E.Malling:Novel Apple Trees.
page.content: East Malling Research Station has done much work on new branchless apple trees which are planted about 3 feet apart and resemble rows of poles. The apples grow on tiny spurs. These trees have been developed from a freak tree found in Brit. Columbia by Mr. Wijcik. An E.M.R.S. scientist visiting Canada, brought back some pollen. After 10 years of crossing and testing, four "columnar" varieties of apple tree have been selected. One is an ornamental crab apple. Two are crosses with Golden Delicious. The last has been crossed with "Malling" Greensleeves. These columnars allow high density orchards, minimal pruning, give good yields within a few years of planting and give scope for mechanisation. These new varieties should be on sale in the near future.
